vWashington House Rabbit Newsv

Volume 6 Issue 4 December 1997
HARE TRANSPLANT OPERATION

On October 19, 1997, veterinarians and volunteers from the Seattle/King County Humane Society, Rabbit Haven, and the House Rabbit Society corralled, examined, and placed 49 rabbits into quarantined area. These rescued rabbits will be adopted into homes or relocated. The enormous ongoing project will remove the rabbit colony from the Redmond business park.


HRS volunteer, Leslie Smith holds one of the
rescued rabbits in her coat

  
HRS volunteer Kelli Adam gathers many rabbits for rescue.


Left to right: Teresa Lee, Kim Weimer, and
Leslie Smith, prepare the quarantine area.

 


Rabbits are placed one per cage and
quarantined until cleared of all diseases
and parasites.

 
Doctors Barbara Deeb and Evelyn Bitner exam each rabbit noting sex, weight, and problems that required further examination.


Sixty-three percent of the rescued rabbits were found to have a deadly liver coccidia. Medications are working and most rabbits have been cleared of the parasite. Once the rabbits are well, they will be removed from quarantine and placed into foster or permanent homes.


Volunteers surrounded the rabbits with a fence making the enclosure smaller and smaller until they were able to pick up the rabbits without chasing.


Rabbit Haven Director, Sue Brennan
holds one of the 49 rescued rabbits.


Glynis Fredericksen, Manager of Shelter Services
at the Seattle/King County Humane Society
donated her services, along with many volunteers.


One rabbit was rescued while pregnant. On October 20, five babies were born under the care of HRS. Mom and babies are doing well with two babies already claimed for adoption.

Photos by: Steven Seiller
